formatted.What we dislike: No router. Great for very simple SPAs, but something like Mithril.js (or Vue. Or Svelte) probably needed for anything of significance (if you don’t mind the build step).

formatted.What is it?: Inbound webhook store and forward proxy.
formatted.What we like: Saves building your own queuing system - acts as a proxy to store and forward webhooks. Set up throttling and retry rules. Mirror inbound webhooks to multiple destinations, including a local CLI for testing. Alerts on failures - allows you to search & retry failures so you don’t lose any data.
formatted.What we dislike: Assumes your webhook destinations are idempotent with “at least once” delivery. No support for signature verification - will forward all requests (you can configure schema filters), so you need to implement this yourself. No support for custom webhook URL domains.

formatted.What we like: Local simulation of the GitHub Actions environment using Docker. Much faster than commit/push for testing changes. Supports environment variables and secrets. Can trigger specific events e.g. pull request, push, and jobs within workflows (including skipping steps).
formatted.What we dislike: Only supports Linux runners (host is multi-platform). Full Docker images are quite large (>20GB), but you can try slimmer images with fewer bundled tools.

formatted.What we like: Packages for all platforms (+ Nix, AUR, musl). Uses relaxed SQL to support fields e.g. size, path; operators e.g. AND, gte, like; date queries e.g. created, modified; filename glob and regex. Can use .gitignore and search MP3, MIME and other file attributes. Output in CSV, JSON, HTML.
formatted.What we dislike: Requires the absolute path (~/path doesn’t work), or searches current working directory if no path provided. Be careful to use quotes if you use shell characters such as >

formatted.What is it?: Execute commands across multiple git repos.
formatted.What we like: Write a script to make a change to a single Git repo, then apply that change across multiple (specified in a list, or entire GitHub Org). Executes in parallel. Can open GitHub PRs with changes. Lots of use cases for otherwise tedious work e.g. name changes, updating dependencies, mass config changes.
formatted.What we dislike: Only supports GitHub PRs, but can push remote branches. Releases only available as binaries, no packages (you can use go get). Sometimes scripting these things actually takes longer than doing it manually.

formatted.What is it?: A multi-threaded high-performance fork of Redis.
formatted.What we like: Drop-in replacement for Redis. Claims x5 speed boost from multi-threading. Adds some extra features like backup to S3 and active replication. Potentially reduces operational complexity by shifting scaling to CPU cores and network throughput rather than requiring clustering.
formatted.What we dislike: Runs the normal Redis event loop on multiple threads which requires locking (low contention, but work ongoing to improve). Expects exclusive use of assigned CPU cores.

formatted.What is it?: An HTTP client for VS Code.
formatted.What we like: Easily build HTTP requests with custom params, auth (basic, bearer, OAuth), headers and body (text, JSON, XML, form, GraphQL). Parses and syntax highlights response, headers and cookies. Can create automated tests with conditions such as response time, status codes, headers, etc.
formatted.What we dislike: All local - no config sync or dynamic loading from config files, but configs can be exported and imported.

formatted.What is it?: Build an API to develop against.
formatted.What we like: Create a read/write REST API to start building against before your backend is ready. Supports all HTTP verbs. Lots of default field types with sample data e.g. location, emails, avatars, credit cards.
formatted.What we dislike: Limited to 150 rows. Hosted by a third party, so don’t send anything sensitive. Deleted after 30 days of inactivity.

formatted.What is it?: CLI for parallelizing commands inside AWS Lambda.
formatted.What we like: Makes it easy to burst parallelizable commands into Lambda. Uses Go template language for managing input and output. Supports Docker wrappers to bootstrap environments. Includes a drop-in GCC/clang replacement for outsourcing compilation.
formatted.What we dislike: Lambda is CPU and memory constrained, and the network is a bottleneck, so use cases are constrained to where parallelization makes a big difference (or there is a benefit to freeing local resources).

formatted.What we like: Single binary (C++) runs natively on Linux and macOS. Tunable ranking for relevancy score tie-breaks. Sort at query-time without additional indexes. Scoped API keys. InstantSearch.js adapter. REST API with clients for JS, PHP, Python, Ruby. Open source + cloud option.
formatted.What we dislike: Need to build your own index updater mechanism to process new data. API-only means you need to build your own UI/admin. Only supports Latin-based languages.

formatted.What we like: Offering webhooks is actually more complex than you'd expect. Diahook deals with signing requests, queueing, retries, reliability, auth, E2E encryption, rate limiting, logs and debugging.
formatted.What we dislike: You need to send your events to Diahook, which means you still need to ensure they get there (retries, debugging, etc).

formatted.What we like: Deals with the underlying infrastructure for reliable task execution: state management, retries, scaling, fault tolerance. Avoid building and running your own timers / queues - just write the function business logic. Open source server you can run yourself, or use their cloud option (in private beta).
formatted.What we dislike: SDKs are still being built out (currently available for Go, Java, PHP, Ruby). You still need to run / scale your own database (Cassandra, MySQL, or PostgreSQL).

formatted.What is it?: API mocking library for frontend developers.
formatted.What we like: Intercepts all XMLHttpRequest and fetch requests so no code changes required (one additional import). Includes in-memory database for persistence tests. Can simulate slow responses or errors. Built-in ORM handles data relationships, output formatting, serialization.
formatted.What we dislike: Only supports REST APIs out of the box - GraphQL available as an optional plugin (still in development). Runs in the browser, not as a server, so it cannot be used to mock server-side APIs.

formatted.What is it?: Git workflow for planning / writing commits in advance.
formatted.What we like: Forces you to think about what you are going to work on in advance - writing out a plan probably helps improve your thinking, and also creates better commit messages. If you think of something you need to switch to, you can create a plan whilst it’s still top-of-mind, then come back to it later.
formatted.What we dislike: Unintuitive to begin with, but makes sense once you try it (see blog posts linked in the project readme for guidance). Interactive rebasing is an alternative that doesn’t force you to reverse your workflow.

formatted.What we like: Quickly create step function APIs from lots of pre-built integrations. Cron support. Connect to external data sources and manipulate data. Write real Python, JS, Java, shell script, GraphQL, HTML, and SQL (including using packaged dependencies) as separate steps. Configurable editor e.g. use vim keybindings, tabs vs spaces, etc.
formatted.What we dislike: Can be slow to execute (many seconds) especially with lots of steps. Have to use their browser editor - can’t develop and run code locally (this is on the roadmap).
